content.description: Super Clean line, definitely climbed long ago.  Rappel down to the obvious ledge about 40feet off the ground. Same start for Gray Corner

From the belay ledge, clip the first bolt before traversing left into immediate exposure. Difficulty gradually increases as you enjoy face climbing around a protection ready seam. Surmount a pillar via a final hard move at the top of the system, then move slightly right to an overhanging, but moderate crack finish.
content.protection: One quickdraw and a double set of C3s, excluding the little grays, a #.3 and optional small nuts. A single bolt anchor can be backed up with an additional #.3 at a good ledge.
content.location: A large dead pine tree stands atop the center of the Hobel Wall. Easily viewed from across the canyon, Highboy lies on the right side of the wall, a few breaks (climbers) right of the dead pine. Once above the Hobel Wall, rappel off of any of the sturdy conifers atop the rim, tossing your rap line several feet left of the dead pine, over a series of small landings before the edge. Abseil to a nice ledge with enough room for a few small people.

content.description: Good to do if going to do Ratrastard
content.location: see Ratrastard beta photo for location.

content.description:
A fair ways past the Cwm Laude Wall, past the broken columnar boulder field, is the Hobel Wall. Named by Paul Rauss as a dedication to the late Mike Hobel. More information under the route "Ratrastard" comments. 

  This wall is more characteristic to Paradise Forks and currently only has a couple of documented routes, though apparently all have been climbed by Rauss in the 90s.
